matchProperty
description:
Will tell if a property defined in a validation and an event matches
Example:
The validation says: 'userStyle.background' and the event says
'userStyle.background', the properties match
The story creator can define a step that just wait for a vague action
to be made:
validation: 'position.*' will match things like 'position.x' and
'position.y'

HardwareAPI
description:
-> Has a [] of parts's models
 -> Receives an event when a new part is added
 -> Receives an event when hw changes
 -> Matches added parts to free devices
 -> Sets matched status to models to update user interface
 ->

name: instanciateDevice
description: Returns an instance of a Device from a device information.

name: getTopDevices
description: Ask a socket the connected devices. Times out after 20 seconds

name: _findFreeMatchingPartForDevice
description: Find an available match for a device

name: addDevice
description: Add and try to find an existing match for the device

name: removeDevice
description: Unbinds and remove a device

name: findOrCreatePartForDevice
description:
Try to match a device to part. Notify of a new Device creation if
no match was found

name: unbindPartFromDevice
description: Find a part matching the device and frees it

name: reassignDevices
description: Wipe all the bindings between parts and devices and rematch them all

name: anyKitDeviceNotReady
description:
A KitDevice will have a devices property with all its
slave devices when it has finished setting up.
Return true if that array is not present yet.

name: lib/hardware/index.js
lib/hardware/kit-device.js
update
description:
A change was detected in the configuration of the Kit.
Update the web socket connections and update all devices

name: updateDevices
description:
Update the list of devices connected to this Kit.
Ensures the web socket connection is opened, then queries the devices.

name: addDevice
description: Add and try to find an existing match for the device

name: removeDevice
description: Unbinds and remove a device

slave devices when it has finished setting up.
Return true if that array is not present yet.

indexOfListener
description: Finds the index of the listener for the event in its storage array.

params.name: listeners
params.description: Array of listeners to search through.

params.name: listener
params.description: Method to look for.

return.description: Index of the specified listener, -1 if not found

name: alias
description: Alias a method while keeping the context correct, to allow for overwriting of target method.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the target method.

return.description: The aliased method

name: getListeners
description:
Returns the listener array for the specified event.
Will initialise the event object and listener arrays if required.
Will return an object if you use a regex search. The object contains keys for each matched event. So /ba[rz]/ might return an object containing bar and baz. But only if you have either defined them with defineEvent or added some listeners to them.
Each property in the object response is an array of listener functions.

params.name: evt
params.description: Name of the event to return the listeners from.

return.description: All listener functions for the event.

name: flattenListeners
description: Takes a list of listener objects and flattens it into a list of listener functions.

params.name: listeners
params.description: Raw listener objects.

return.description: Just the listener functions.

name: getListenersAsObject
description: Fetches the requested listeners via getListeners but will always return the results inside an object. This is mainly for internal use but others may find it useful.

params.name: evt
params.description: Name of the event to return the listeners from.

return.description: All listener functions for an event in an object.

name: addListener
description:
Adds a listener function to the specified event.
The listener will not be added if it is a duplicate.
If the listener returns true then it will be removed after it is called.
If you pass a regular expression as the event name then the listener will be added to all events that match it.

params.name: evt
params.description: Name of the event to attach the listener to.

params.name: listener
params.description: Method to be called when the event is emitted. If the function returns true then it will be removed after calling.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: addOnceListener
description:
Semi-alias of addListener. It will add a listener that will be
automatically removed after its first execution.

params.name: evt
params.description: Name of the event to attach the listener to.

params.name: listener
params.description: Method to be called when the event is emitted. If the function returns true then it will be removed after calling.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: defineEvent
description:
Defines an event name. This is required if you want to use a regex to add a listener to multiple events at once. If you don't do this then how do you expect it to know what event to add to? Should it just add to every possible match for a regex? No. That is scary and bad.
You need to tell it what event names should be matched by a regex.

params.name: evt
params.description: Name of the event to create.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: defineEvents
description: Uses defineEvent to define multiple events.

params.name: evts
params.description: An array of event names to define.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: removeListener
description:
Removes a listener function from the specified event.
When passed a regular expression as the event name, it will remove the listener from all events that match it.

params.name: evt
params.description: Name of the event to remove the listener from.

params.name: listener
params.description: Method to remove from the event.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: addListeners
description:
Adds listeners in bulk using the manipulateListeners method.
If you pass an object as the first argument you can add to multiple events at once. The object should contain key value pairs of events and listeners or listener arrays. You can also pass it an event name and an array of listeners to be added.
You can also pass it a regular expression to add the array of listeners to all events that match it.
Yeah, this function does quite a bit. That's probably a bad thing.

params.name: evt
params.description: An event name if you will pass an array of listeners next. An object if you wish to add to multiple events at once.

params.name: listeners
params.description: An optional array of listener functions to add.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: removeListeners
description:
Removes listeners in bulk using the manipulateListeners method.
If you pass an object as the first argument you can remove from multiple events at once. The object should contain key value pairs of events and listeners or listener arrays.
You can also pass it an event name and an array of listeners to be removed.
You can also pass it a regular expression to remove the listeners from all events that match it.

params.name: evt
params.description: An event name if you will pass an array of listeners next. An object if you wish to remove from multiple events at once.

params.name: listeners
params.description: An optional array of listener functions to remove.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: manipulateListeners
description:
Edits listeners in bulk. The addListeners and removeListeners methods both use this to do their job. You should really use those instead, this is a little lower level.
The first argument will determine if the listeners are removed (true) or added (false).
If you pass an object as the second argument you can add/remove from multiple events at once. The object should contain key value pairs of events and listeners or listener arrays.
You can also pass it an event name and an array of listeners to be added/removed.
You can also pass it a regular expression to manipulate the listeners of all events that match it.

params.name: remove
params.description: True if you want to remove listeners, false if you want to add.

params.name: evt
params.description: An event name if you will pass an array of listeners next. An object if you wish to add/remove from multiple events at once.

params.name: listeners
params.description: An optional array of listener functions to add/remove.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: removeEvent
description:
Removes all listeners from a specified event.
If you do not specify an event then all listeners will be removed.
That means every event will be emptied.
You can also pass a regex to remove all events that match it.

params.name: evt
params.description: Optional name of the event to remove all listeners for. Will remove from every event if not passed.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: emitEvent
description:
Emits an event of your choice.
When emitted, every listener attached to that event will be executed.
If you pass the optional argument array then those arguments will be passed to every listener upon execution.
Because it uses `apply`, your array of arguments will be passed as if you wrote them out separately.
So they will not arrive within the array on the other side, they will be separate.
You can also pass a regular expression to emit to all events that match it.

params.name: evt
params.description: Name of the event to emit and execute listeners for.

params.name: args
params.description: Optional array of arguments to be passed to each listener.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: emit
description:
Subtly different from emitEvent in that it will pass its arguments on to the listeners, as opposed to taking a single array of arguments to pass on.
As with emitEvent, you can pass a regex in place of the event name to emit to all events that match it.

params.name: evt
params.description: Name of the event to emit and execute listeners for.

params.name: Optional
params.description: additional arguments to be passed to each listener.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: setOnceReturnValue
description:
Sets the current value to check against when executing listeners. If a
listeners return value matches the one set here then it will be removed
after execution. This value defaults to true.

params.name: value
params.description: The new value to check for when executing listeners.

return.description: Current instance of EventEmitter for chaining.

name: _getOnceReturnValue
description:
Fetches the current value to check against when executing listeners. If
the listeners return value matches this one then it should be removed
automatically. It will return true by default.

return.description: The current value to check for or the default, true.

name: _getEvents
description: Fetches the events object and creates one if required.

return.description: The events storage object.

name: EventEmitter
description:
Class for managing events.
Can be extended to provide event functionality in other classes.

unknown.tagValue: EventEmitter Manages event registering and emitting.

name: lib/util/import.js
lib/util/subscription.js
charMap
description: charMap

name: lookAheadCharArray
description:
special look ahead character array
These characters form with consonants to become 'single'/consonant combo

name: diatricMap
description: diatricMap for languages where transliteration changes entirely as more diatrics are added

name: langCharMap
description: langCharMap language specific characters translations

name: symbolMap
description:
symbolMap language specific symbol translations
translations must be transliterated already

name: createSlug
description: createSlug curried(opts)(input)

params.name: opts
params.description: config object or input string

return.description: function getSlugWithConfig()

name: escapeChars
description: escape Chars

params.name: input
params.description: string

name: isReplacedCustomChar
description: check if the char is an already converted char from custom list

params.name: ch
params.description: character to check

params.name: customReplacements
params.description: custom translation map

name: getSlug
description: getSlug

params.name: input
params.description: input string

params.name: opts
params.description: config object or separator string/char

return.description: sluggified string

name: lib/vm.js

content:
# Kano Code

## Usage

```js
import { Editor } from '@kano/code/index.js';

const editor = new Editor({ sourceType: 'blockly' });

editor.inject(document.body);

```

## The editor

[Editor's documentation](./app/lib/editor/README.md)

[Challenges documentation](./app/lib/challenge/README.md)

## Development

### Setup

```bash
yarn
```

### Serve

```bash
yarn serve
```

### Demos

While serving, visit any of those:

http://localhost:4000/demo/simple/index.html
http://localhost:4000/demo/pong/index.html

# Most of the documentation after this point is outdated:
-----

## Make it work

In the main folder, install the dependencies :

npm is used for the gulp tasks
bower is used for the web UI components (Polymer...)

```shell
npm install
bower install
```

Everything works out of the box in terms of development. You can start a server with `app` as root and Kano Code will load.
For convenience, a gulp task was added. It starts a server with the right root and reloads the browser everytime a file changes.
To run it just use

```shell
gulp watch
```

## Take a snapshot of the app to be distributed with `kano-content`
Check out the branch you want to take a snapshot of and follow these instructions:

1. Run: `npm run content-snap`

2. If everything goes well a file called `assets.tar.gz` will be created in the root dir of the repository.
3. Use the online interface to upload it to `kano-content`

## Testing workflow on Kano OS

Because of some native extensions of some dependencies, `npm install`
fails on the Pi. There are currently 2 documented methods of syncing the
changes from your local dev machine to a Pi for testing, without having to
wait for the build server to generate a debian package.

### Get local changes to the Pi (Follow either method):
#### Use provided script
We have created a bash script that reduces the no of steps to allow for
shorter iterations. To use it, do the following:
1. From the root of this repository run: `push_to_pi.sh`
(You may need to set the executable bit on this script)
2. The location of your files are printed on your terminal.

If you need to iterate change the files on your local machine and re run the
script. It will only copy over the diff of the files so subsequent times will
be faster than the first time.

Feel free to improve this script :-)


#### Do it manually
The easiest way to test on the Pi is to build on
your dev machine and rsync the directory to over. Like this:

```bash
    cd make-apps/
    npm install
    bower install
    npm build
    rsync -av -e 'ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no' --exclude=.git --exclude=node_modules . "kano@10.0.0.231:/tmp/radek-make-apps"
```

### Access the app on the kit (assumes you rsynced or used the script -see above)
The next steps are:

* Get on your Pi (direct or via VNC)
* Open the terminal
* `cd /tmp/radek-make-apps/rpi/bin` (hint: use your own name here to avoid clashes with others)
* `./make-apps`
* The app should start loading

To debug, you'll need to rebuild the app, rsync again and relaunch it on the Pi.

### Notes on using HQ test station

If you'd like to quickly try things out, there's a test station in the office:

* IP: 10.0.0.231
* ssh user: kano
* ssh pass: kano
* vnc pass: online

You can ssh/vnc into it and try things out. There's a cron job that keeps our nightly
builds of Kano Code up-to-date on it if you just want to check that `master` works.
For testing features you're working on, see the workflow above.

# I18N

You can generate the `.pot` files to sync them with the pootle server by running `gulp pot`. The files will be generated in the `app/po` folder

# Testing & Deployment

## Testing

The task `test:local` is present in gulp and will perform unit tests on individual components (WIP)
Functional tests are located in `tests/` and can be run with `cucumber-js test/`. At the moment, it will spawn a static server and run tests using `selenium-webdriver`. The tests expects `make-apps` to be built for a staging environment.
You can choose the target browser by setting the env variable `TARGET_BROWSER` to `chrome`, `firefox` or `safari`, will default to `chrome` (WIP)

### Staging

Master is automatically deployed by Jenkins. Can be found here: http://apps-staging.kano.me/

### Production

Production is served from S3. Can be found here: http://apps.kano.me
name: ./README.md

content:
{
  "description": "",
  "repository": {
    "type": "git",
    "url": "https://github.com/KanoComputing/kano-code.git"
  },
  "name": "@kano/code",
  "version": "3.0.0-beta.1",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "gulp serve-prod",
    "test": "gulp wct && cucumber-js tests --format=json > test-results/cucumber.json",
    "build": "gulp build",
    "dev": "gulp dev",
    "watch": "gulp watch",
    "content-snap": "bash kano-content-package.sh",
    "install:all": "npm install && bower install",
    "install:all:build": "npm install && bower install && gulp build",
    "build-engine": "gulp build-engine",
    "serve": "node ./tasks/serve",
    "docs": "esdoc"
  },
  "author": "Paul Varache <perso@paulvarache.ninja>",
  "license": "ISC",
  "devDependencies": {
    "@kano/es6-resolution": "^1.0.7",
    "@polymer/iron-component-page": "^3.0.0-pre.18",
    "@polymer/iron-demo-helpers": "^3.0.0-pre.18",
    "@polymer/iron-test-helpers": "^3.0.0-pre.18",
    "@polymer/neon-animation": "^3.0.0-pre.18",
    "@polymer/paper-toolbar": "^3.0.0-pre.18",
    "babel-preset-env": "^1.1.8",
    "blessed": "^0.1.81",
    "chai": "^4.1.2",
    "chalk": "^1.1.3",
    "connect": "^3.6.0",
    "connect-history-api-fallback": "^1.5.0",
    "connect-livereload": "^0.6.0",
    "cucumber": "^3.0.0",
    "esdoc": "^1.1.0",
    "esdoc-standard-plugin": "^1.0.0",
    "gulp": "^3.9.1",
